Friend: in this particular case it's not very telling because we didn't see any correlation with behaviour
Friend: but read the first paragraph here
Persona: like entrepreneurs show a higher dmpfc activation when it comes to getting rewards for oneself, while managers show higher activation when the rewards is not for them. If you had you translate this to a general business newspaper article headline, how would it sound?

Persona: Is dmpfc high/low somehow related to exploration/explotation?
Persona: exploitation*
Persona: Even if there are no behavioral differences. if the brain activations are different that might show something about the difference between man and ent. Especially if I could know what those activations mean generally. Like if higher dmpfc activation is also present when eating ice cream during winter, then that might tell me that entrepreneurs taking risk has something in common with eating ice cream during winter
Persona: the example is stupid
Persona: but
Persona: I hope you get the pount
Friend: not to my knowledge. we investigated that region bc it has been shown previously that it may be involved in differentiation between decisions made for self and others (see 1st paragraph below). that's actually a useful result of our study bc it adds evidence to that hypothesis
Friend: in a perfect world yes, but in reality it is possible that this effect is due to chance. fMRI is not a terribly reliable or replicable method, so take that with a rain of salt
Friend: nothing is really this straightforward in neuroscience, but thats a long conversation
Persona: google is being really helpful
Friend: valence is just positive or negative
Persona: ok so basically, I can't really raise the findings of your thesis above the neuroscience sea level, and it mostly concerns other neuroscience research. It can't show something to someone not in neuroscience yet.
Persona: would that be right?
Friend: I think that's a good way to look at it. it's useful for the sake of perfecting the methodology (both in terms of what to do and what not to do), but we haven't really come any closer to understanding what differentiates entrepreneurs from the gen. population

Persona is surveyed about their personality. The persona must choose answer the question below with one of the given options: DISAGREE, SOMEWHAT DISAGREE, NEUTRAL, SOMEWHAT AGREE, AGREE. Persona's answer must only contain the chosen option. 
I am the life of the party.

You are specialized in impersonating people. You will be presented to the subject through explicit datapoints of their digital footprint. In addition, you will deduct their implicit tastes by shadowing chats between the subject and friends. You will be asked to answer questions from the point of view of the persona. Text below:
Conversations between persona and friends
Friend: oh god no. I'm not getting involved in diy closing of any leaks ever again
Persona: I was thinking about the "if there's no one who matches my excitement about sth" thing a bit. I actually may be dependent on this one aswell, and I think I end up trying to force it upon people. Perhaps I even showed you my weird AI pong experiment haha. I usually spam my best friend, who knows a bit of nerdy stuff, I don't know how sustainable is that cause I might be ultra annoying but he does not tell me.
Persona: Now I think that maybe I stopped that AI pong because I ran out of unique impressions from other people xd
Persona: this I totally get. It might be paradigm in the world about coding, data science and nerdy things. I really god damn want to find all the needed evidence to break this belief, but I am not getting close to this
Persona: at the company I work we have engineering team and sales team. The sales people are extreme extroverts. I could not believe people can be so extroverted, it came as a shock to me. They just never stop interacting. The engineers only talk to each other. Most of them never show up to friday bars and the one guy that does, he is like the cool engineer dude, I can still see that he is lonely sometimes in parties. I am in a position between both of them. And this position is so weird. So this might be an ultimate dilemma whether to pursue nerdy things or not
Persona: I just came back from my company retreat which held us in Sweden for a few days (and thus sorry for responding late, it was very intense) and I kept thinking about being inward and outward at the same time. I spent my holiday very inward and I am semi-inward at work and then tried to be outward but I can't just switch instantly and I had a bad experience.
Persona: Wonder if you thats also how you felt
Persona: I haven't tried to convince you yet. I am not sure if I should haha, I haven't tested it yet.
Persona: But basically, gathering as much data as possible before taking action is very costly and I would say you still can't eliminate all risk.
Persona: And sometimes taking a bit of action, even if its a wrong one, can reveal so much more and get you deeper knowledge faster than research.
Persona: Of course if one is making million dollar decisions, then each extra knowledge might be worth it. Thats why I say learning to use gut feeling is more relevant for startup founders. And speed, non-bureaucracy, little administrative burden is a big advantage of startups.
Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. So perhaps it's better to fail two startups in three years and learn so much for the third one, than spend multiple years looking for a perfect idea with no real-world experience.
Friend: AI ping pong. I actually do have a memory of looking at it, but don't remember what was that all about...what was that all about?
Friend: and he hasn't unfriended you yet. you must be doing something right 🤷‍♀️👏
Friend: you know, I think it may seem  it's a STEM people thing due to introverts being overrepresented in that group. I definitely do see people from other walks of life experience this as well

Friend: the thing about being in-between - I get it. personally, I do have to go to different people for different things a lot, because I've never really been able to get all my social needs met by one friend group. love talking to nerds, but you can't really drag them downtown to a rave. love party people, but I don't know how to connect with them on a deeper level. sciencey people are awesome when I've just learnt about some cool study I want to discuss, but I'm not nearly as logical and grounded as them. once I started volunteering at cultural events here in cph, I've realized how much I missed the freedom and creativity of artsy people. and so on. I don't know if I belong everywhere or nowhere, but I guess it is what it is
Friend: but in your case it could be an asset. I guess if you want to be in charge of sth larger, you need to be able to communicate with all sorts of people
Friend: hahah, yes. it feels like I'm in some sort of a locked in syndrome. my brain is happy to finally encounter some people, but cannot remember for shit how a conversation works

Friend: I've just realized that we have different types of choices in mind. I was thinking more generally, and you're referring specifically to business decisions. when I make big decisions, they usually concern the important turns in the trajectory of my own life, so my most precious resource is time. cannot really afford to lose too much of that. but when it comes to money and other renewable things, yeah, I think it's easier to just fuck around and learn from experience (I know you still invest and lose time here, but I guess it's not the main concern)

Persona: I don't like page based, because a big task in note-taking is deciding where to put what and then deciding where to look for what. If you also need to think about pages, then its an extra variable in your decision making process.
Persona: Logseq automates that, so any single block can be a page, you just press on it to zoom in and it becomes the root element
Persona: But they also have pages (which is sometimes till needed so files don't get too large and if you want to collaborate, so you can work in diff files, like in coding)

Persona: But basically, gathering as much data as possible before taking action is very costly and I would say you still can't eliminate all risk.
Persona: And sometimes taking a bit of action, even if its a wrong one, can reveal so much more and get you deeper knowledge faster than research.
Persona: Of course if one is making million dollar decisions, then each extra knowledge might be worth it. Thats why I say learning to use gut feeling is more relevant for startup founders. And speed, non-bureaucracy, little administrative burden is a big advantage of startups.
Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. Persona: Recently, I've been doing a lot of networking and then also trying to purposely use network as a resource and also seen people use it and it worked wonders. At this point I became really interested in the topic itself, not necessarily how to find new people, but more like how to deepen connections to 'unlock new possibilities with each person' (if that makes sense). At this point of planning to make a system of how I take note of these things, ensure completeness and reflect on methods. And also coming up with conversational methods on how to deepen connections.

This is already slithly weird, but this get weirder. I read a book a while ago, that is still my faav book. "How to win friends and influence people" - the author shares some fundamental ways in dealing with people, making them like you (and thus new levels on possibilities) and leveraging them. I will use his methods to sort of get deeper connections. Its a little forced, but one of the fundamental things is that I should find something about people that interests me aswell, so its not so forced - makes it easier, more impactful and sincere-looking I think.
Persona: The fact that I am taking this so serious is sounds quite weird, but honestly, weird things worked out wonders for me in the past, so I will keep up with it.

Persona: But basically, gathering as much data as possible before taking action is very costly and I would say you still can't eliminate all risk.
Persona: And sometimes taking a bit of action, even if its a wrong one, can reveal so much more and get you deeper knowledge faster than research.
Persona: Of course if one is making million dollar decisions, then each extra knowledge might be worth it. Thats why I say learning to use gut feeling is more relevant for startup founders. And speed, non-bureaucracy, little administrative burden is a big advantage of startups.
Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).

Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).

Persona: But basically, gathering as much data as possible before taking action is very costly and I would say you still can't eliminate all risk.
Persona: And sometimes taking a bit of action, even if its a wrong one, can reveal so much more and get you deeper knowledge faster than research.
Persona: Of course if one is making million dollar decisions, then each extra knowledge might be worth it. Thats why I say learning to use gut feeling is more relevant for startup founders. And speed, non-bureaucracy, little administrative burden is a big advantage of startups.
Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. So perhaps it's better to fail two startups in three years and learn so much for the third one, than spend multiple years looking for a perfect idea with no real-world experience.

Persona: But basically, gathering as much data as possible before taking action is very costly and I would say you still can't eliminate all risk.
Persona: And sometimes taking a bit of action, even if its a wrong one, can reveal so much more and get you deeper knowledge faster than research.
Persona: Of course if one is making million dollar decisions, then each extra knowledge might be worth it. Thats why I say learning to use gut feeling is more relevant for startup founders. And speed, non-bureaucracy, little administrative burden is a big advantage of startups.
Persona: Another kind of related thing is that (generally) the more failed startups one experiences, the higher the chance that the next will be better. Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).

Persona: I didn't like obsidian because it has stupid functionality for block references. Its more page based.
Persona: And it also has much more primitived block embed functinality (make a editable reference to a block). You edit in point A, it changes in Point B and vice versa. On Logseq this is possible, fully native, and easy.
Persona: Thats the feature I was dreaming about in MindManager for so long
Persona: I don't like page based, because a big task in note-taking is deciding where to put what and then deciding where to look for what. If you also need to think about pages, then its an extra variable in your decision making process.
Persona: Logseq automates that, so any single block can be a page, you just press on it to zoom in and it becomes the root element
Persona: But they also have pages (which is sometimes till needed so files don't get too large and if you want to collaborate, so you can work in diff files, like in coding)
Persona: The only issue with Logseq is that its less stable and feels a little weirder and less polished than Obsidian. Obsidian is super smooth
Persona: Next semester I will try switching uni notes to Logseq, but I am a little anxious. There will be many improvements with that - like I can't wait till I can use block embeds, also I will be able to share my notes with other people in a standardized format. Search functionality is better too.
Persona: But I am anxious that the mindmap layout presentation will turn out to be much more superior to bullet list presentation when it comes to complex topics I will study. Also in Logseq there is less options for content visual customization, so making things standout is more limited (bolding, colors still work).

Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).

Persona: I don't like page based, because a big task in note-taking is deciding where to put what and then deciding where to look for what. If you also need to think about pages, then its an extra variable in your decision making process.
Persona: Logseq automates that, so any single block can be a page, you just press on it to zoom in and it becomes the root element
Persona: But they also have pages (which is sometimes till needed so files don't get too large and if you want to collaborate, so you can work in diff files, like in coding)
Persona: The only issue with Logseq is that its less stable and feels a little weirder and less polished than Obsidian. Obsidian is super smooth
Persona: Next semester I will try switching uni notes to Logseq, but I am a little anxious. There will be many improvements with that - like I can't wait till I can use block embeds, also I will be able to share my notes with other people in a standardized format. Search functionality is better too.
Persona: But I am anxious that the mindmap layout presentation will turn out to be much more superior to bullet list presentation when it comes to complex topics I will study. Also in Logseq there is less options for content visual customization, so making things standout is more limited (bolding, colors still work).

Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).

Persona: I don't like page based, because a big task in note-taking is deciding where to put what and then deciding where to look for what. If you also need to think about pages, then its an extra variable in your decision making process.
Persona: Logseq automates that, so any single block can be a page, you just press on it to zoom in and it becomes the root element
Persona: But they also have pages (which is sometimes till needed so files don't get too large and if you want to collaborate, so you can work in diff files, like in coding)
Persona: The only issue with Logseq is that its less stable and feels a little weirder and less polished than Obsidian. Obsidian is super smooth
Persona: Next semester I will try switching uni notes to Logseq, but I am a little anxious. There will be many improvements with that - like I can't wait till I can use block embeds, also I will be able to share my notes with other people in a standardized format. Search functionality is better too.
Persona: But I am anxious that the mindmap layout presentation will turn out to be much more superior to bullet list presentation when it comes to complex topics I will study. Also in Logseq there is less options for content visual customization, so making things standout is more limited (bolding, colors still work).

Persona: I don't like page based, because a big task in note-taking is deciding where to put what and then deciding where to look for what. If you also need to think about pages, then its an extra variable in your decision making process.
Persona: Logseq automates that, so any single block can be a page, you just press on it to zoom in and it becomes the root element
Persona: But they also have pages (which is sometimes till needed so files don't get too large and if you want to collaborate, so you can work in diff files, like in coding)
Persona: The only issue with Logseq is that its less stable and feels a little weirder and less polished than Obsidian. Obsidian is super smooth
Persona: Next semester I will try switching uni notes to Logseq, but I am a little anxious. There will be many improvements with that - like I can't wait till I can use block embeds, also I will be able to share my notes with other people in a standardized format. Search functionality is better too.
Persona: But I am anxious that the mindmap layout presentation will turn out to be much more superior to bullet list presentation when it comes to complex topics I will study. Also in Logseq there is less options for content visual customization, so making things standout is more limited (bolding, colors still work).

Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).

Persona: I am reflecting upon my uncontrolled burst of gaming.

I was gaming sober for 6 week before this happened. 4 weeks I was feeling no need for it. in the 5th week I already started missing it, thinking about it.
Persona: Then I got mildly sick, not even fever, but that sort of a gave me a final push to do some gaming
Persona: So I spent thursday evening and whole friday gaming till 8 AM Saturday morning
Persona: Then whole Saturday I had my infamous 'gaming hangover', where I treat myself with whatever I want, but just not playing games, so I spent whole day watching RImworld videos an looking at mods. Original plan was to watch a movie, but RImworld videos are also endless fun.
Persona: I am thunking how to preceed in the future
Persona: Do I try again? and most likely try again, again again? Or aknowledge this as inevitability and start thinking damage control mode?
Persona: Trying again is what I have been doing all my university life almost. Gaming didn't have a big bad impact on my life, but sometimes it fucks me up with some deadlines and timing is hard control. Plus it gives me the existential crisis regarding not allowing myself to do something I really like.
Persona: I tried a different strategy lately, where whole holiday period I planned to do nothing but gaming. Highly premeditated, allocated, almost no tasks to do, full freedom. Will a planned stop at New Years.
Persona: All I did was gaming. It was exhilarating on one hand, playing the Minecraft modpacks, especially the Create mod made me feel so good and happy, engaged. The downside was that my life balance was completelly off. Through these 10 days, my physical health really deterioted - I was too busy gaming to take care of myself.
Persona: Also I got some social inneptness after that, just after nolifing we had a yearly kickoff at work. I was really unready for it
Persona: But then after this huge gaming. I got a huge productivity boost
Persona: During those 4 weeks in January I was a true productvity 'superhuman'.
Persona: In my mind I didn't have a plan when to do gaming again. I actually thought I do now want to gaming during Christmas again, since I felt very lonely sometimes. Summer is also such a great time outside that I do no want to do gaming. Other seasons are full of school. And if I get a break sometime - I haven't travelled anywhere for a while, so I must do that.*

Another thing of not planning the next gaming days is that when I planneed them on christmas, 1-2 months prior I was already thinking about it too much. Having little gaming sessions, comparing modpacks, etc. I lost productivity. But I have only tried it once and that might have been just a skill issue as having little control to delay gaming.

But the whole thing of not gaming - it might not be a skill issue. I tried to get better at it - it just doesnt work. And trying the same again and expecting it to work would define insanity.
Persona: Maybe the right way is to set sometime every month, when I have to do gaming. And to do it in balanced way hopefully.
Persona: I am probably looking at  a 'weekend of gaming'.
Persona: But perhaps that is me giving up? Is giving up bad? Or maybe its a case where you have to give up on a fight in order to win the war?
Persona: Another option would be to try justifying gaming.
1) one way that GPT keeps suggesting is that everybody has to relax in life. And gaming is a form of relaxation. 
In my experience it did work regarding the brain (the undisturbed superhuman producvity I had for 4-5 weeks). It did not work regarding physical relaxation - I neglected my physical body. 
Also is it an inferior relaxation method? Compared to partying, spending time with friends or family - it build connections, relations with people, social skills. I build less of thinking ability and creativity - something gaming builds. 
I feel its also publicly despised. I remember having to lie to many people what I will do/did during Christmas.
Persona: 2) another way of justifying would be to do gaming in a more meaningful way for oneself. For me one way would be making youtube videos about it, so if its Rimworld, then doing some advanced play where I record and the interpret and narrate the story over it (very popular kind of content on YT).
Another way would be making mods for RimWorld - that way I would learn some development too.

This will add a lot of non-gaming to gaming, so it has a risk of not working i satisfying my need.
For the second one, the act of purposely justifying it might not be the best act conceptually. Irrationality of a part of being human and going against that may be Sisyphean. 
There is also a chance it will result in taking more time overall, which wouln't be so bad as it is somewhat meaningful now, but its still less meaningfull that doing the things that directly work (founding a startup, studying, building prototypes, networking) towards my dream (build multiple successfull startups).
